Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2014 07:42AM Trisha-Anne wrote: Like Flannelette I had FEC. I tolerated FEC fairly well. Had taste changes - nothing really tasted very good, but water was ok. I also took all the precautions to avoid mouth sores, but did get a couple. I'm trying to remember all the anti-nausea meds they gave me. I know one was Emend and I took one very big tablet just as they were starting chemo, and had two tablets to take one on each of the next two days. I also had dexamethasone and ondansetron. I took all the meds I was supposed to when I was supposed to and never threw up once. I did feel quite queasy from time to time, but never threw up :-) You need to make sure you take the meds they give you at the times they tell you to. It's easier to stop nausea before it starts. Once you start throwing up it's very hard to stop. I also had very bad diarrhea - some people get constipated, others get the big D. Be prepared for either. My hair fell out too. Head hair to start with then every single hair on my body fell out lol - even my nose hair! My worst days were 3 and 4 after infusion, then I started to pick up. I didn't have Taxol - I had Taxotere and it nearly killed me. I couldn't finish it. So - for me at least FEC was very doable, soooo much better than the taxane. If I had to do chemo again, I wouldn't worry too much if it was FEC, I think I'd have to pass on a taxane though - too rough on my body. Taxol and Taxotere are part of the taxane group. Good luck! Trish
Posts.Title: If you've had the FAC combo of chemo, please respond! texas94 texas94

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2014 07:38AM Trisha-Anne wrote: Texas - good to hear from you :-) So glad the FAC isn't too hard on you. Just take it easy - listen to your body, rest and sleep as much as you need to. You'll get through this eventually - and like me be four years out and having trouble remembering it all lol. Trish xoxo
Posts.Title: If you've had the FAC combo of chemo, please respond! texas94 texas94

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2012 08:56PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Veronica I had 3 FEC and was supposed to have 3 of the Docetaxol - which is Taxtoere - not Taxol. FEC was not too bad - as everyone has said here - lots of water, take all the anti nausea meds, whether you think you need them or not, that will help a lot with the nausea.  I was never constipated - I was always the opposite lots of diahorrea.  My hair fell out around day 14.  I'd feel ok on the day of transfusion - would have a bad headache that night and be ok for a couple of days. Days 4 and 5 were bad for me. Taxoetere was altogether a different kettle of fish.  I ended up only having 2 doses.  Second dose was decreased substantially, but my body couldn't tolerate the drug.  On Taxotere my eyelashes and eyebrows fell out along with every single hair on my body - even in my nose lol but interestingly enough I started to grow some stubble on my head.  I had no nausea on T but flu like symptoms (very, very bad) along with mouth ulcers, heartburn, diarhoea (extreme) blistering on my private parts and extreme taste changes.  Even the air I was breathing smelled like a chemical.  Water tasted like mud which made it hard to keep hydrated. I need to stress though - not everyone will get these se's - we are all different, and you may not have any of them, or they may be mild.  I was just one of those who couldn't tolerate it - hence not doing the last dose. I am almost 12 months out now - and my hair, eyelashes and eyebrows (and all the other hairs) have grown back.  And I feel great! It's a long, hard road, but you can do it!  Trish
Posts.Title: Have you had the FEC -D protocol? VeronicaX VeronicaX

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2013 12:19PM Trisha-Anne wrote: I had an MRI last month, my first one. I've had many scans, that involve injecting a dye and never had any problems. The MRI machine was a brand new one and I was the first breast patient to use it.  I have no food allergies at all, but when injected with the dye I had a reaction and threw up.  Luckily that's all that happened, and within an hour or so was back to normal. I think the dr and nurse were more alarmed than me, I was just embarrased that I'd "christened" their brand new machine, but I didn't realise that a reaction to the dye can kill you. They took good care of me, and when the radiologist said he'd see me in 12 months for another one I said "really?" He laughed and said they'd use a different dye and I should be ok. Trish
Posts.Title: Risks of MRI Scaredandworried Trisha-Anne

Posts.Content: May 28, 2013 08:44PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Hi Alibeths Your poor love, it's scary to contemplate, but please don't panic.  I had my port put in four days prior to the first chemo, and was so worried about the whole chemo thing and how it was going to hurt when the port was accessed, I actually had a siezure as they were prepping me for chemo.  Spent the day in ER instead.  Was so angry and frustrated with myself.  When I went back in two days later there was no hitch and it all went very well. As Annie said - you are usually pampered a bit - lovely recliner to sit in, warm blankets, food, water etc and the nurses fussing over you. My advice would be to take the Xanax (is that diazapam?) before you go in.  For your port - I'm usually not too bad with needles, but was pretty terrified about the needle they use to access the port (it's really not that bad) and I got some Emla cream.  Not sure if it's called the same thing over there - but it's an aneasethetic for your skin.  I'd put a pretty good dollop on the skin over the port and cover it with a plastic "bandagey type of thing" lol - don't know how else to describe it - sort of like Glad Wrap - Saran Wrap I think you guys call it? And left it for at least 3 hours before the port was to be accessed - and I never felt a thing :-) The main thing is to drink lots of water on the day you get chemo - as well as the following days, but as you are getting it to keep your bladder flushed - some chemos can be harsh on the bladder. Apart from that - depending on the type of chemo you are getting there's not too much to do to prepare.  If you are getting a taxane - ie taxotere, taxol etc you can ice your fingers, paint your nails black etc to minimise nail loss.  Some women have this happen - I never did.  I didn't ice, but I had lovely black polished fingernails for a couple of treatments lol. Make sure you bring something to keep you occupied - a movie to watch, a book to read, knitting or whatever you are into.  Chemo infusions can take a while. I was never allowed to have an infusion unless there was someone to drive me home.  My DH came with me, but as the treatments went on - I sent him out to do other things while I was there so I could relax and not worry about him being bored. Good luck with it - keep us informed, and ask if you have any questions at all. I'm over 2 years past chemo - and doing very well, feeling wonderful and on top of the world. (((((hugs)))) Trish
Posts.Title: The night before chemo????? Alibeths Alibeths

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2011 03:19PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Hi rabbit Sounds like you are getting things under control. I found that the taste changes weren't too bad on FEC - it was the Taxotere where it was awful.  My main source of food was hard boiled eggs, a little cheese, chocolate icecream and creamed rice.  I also found that lemon in the water made it taste worse.  By the last treatment the one thing that didn't taste really bad was a bit of red cordial in my water. My hair started falling out at day 17.  By my second treatment I was totally bald.  But - something to keep your focus - it really does grow back.  I'm now 4 months out of chemo and I have a good half an inch covering my head now, it's even starting to curl a bit lol  I have a port too - but won't get it out until after my herceptin is finished, which I think will be early January.  The port doesn't bother me at all any more, I forget it's there most of the time. oandtolivo - you hang in there too - remember just one day at a  time :-) Trish xoxox
Posts.Title: sick on the first day? rabbit rabbit

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2011 02:17AM Trisha-Anne wrote: Hi Emily I did three cycles of FEC and found them doable.  Not great - but doable.  My bad days were around 4 and 5, and those days I would have bad diarroeha and feel queasy, but never sick.  I usually ended up with a migraine on the night of the infusion. I also got very tired, and found that the tiredness was cumulative.  I had taste changes too - but they generally lasted around 5 or 6 days and not extreme.  My main food was cheese on toast, the only thing that didn't taste like cardboard, and lots and lots of water. I'm now on Taxotere - and FEC was a walk in the park compared to this. Hugs to you Trish

Irr4993 and patty61 - that puts my mind at rest a bit.  I just need to know what might happen - then I can deal with things a lot better. mrsnjband - I don't think I'll like the se's either - but I'm going to go in with the attitude that I'm not going to have any se's at all, and if wishful thinking helps then I'll wish a lot :-)

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 09:14PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Thanks everyone for your reply - you have set my mind at ease.  I'll be prepared and will make sure I take my valium in the morning, so hopefully won't care too much about something that might not happen lol lago - I've been told that for the Taxotere I won't be getting Emend - as it's no longer needed and our government doesn't cover it for Taxotere.  Hopefully my onc is right and nausea isn't an issue for these treatments.  I do have the dexamethasone to start tomorrow - but I've also been given sleeping tablets in case they affect my sleeping. I'll let you all know how it goes - but I'm now not so worried. Thank you all Trish

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 01:20AM Trisha-Anne wrote: Sue I'm only making a co-payment towards all the meds - it's $33 per script only for drugs that are very expensive - everything else (if it's a cheapie - like $15 or so) is free.  So it's not too bad - I'm not complaining too much.  $200 compared to around $5000 (or more)  for some of the treatments is ok.  I was given the dexamethasone at the last treatment to take with me to start today - so if it's expensive it'll show up on the next bill.  Seems each state is a bit different too. Thanks for the good luck - I'm doing it every three weeks, so I guess the dose will be higher than the weekly ones.  I'm defenitely not having any bad se's from this - I've decided lol!!

Posts.Content: Trisha-Anne wrote: Hello everyone I have my first Taxotere infusion on Monday and then one every three weeks for three cycles.  I've been told that I could have an allergic reaction to the infusion on either the first or second (or both) infusions.  Has anyone had this happen?  I will start on steroids on Sunday, and take them on Monday and Tuesday.  But I must admit I'm a little worried about this reaction.  Is it as bad as my mind is starting to make it? I have made a long journey and been to a strange land and I've seen the dark man very close ... Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2012 03:03AM Trisha-Anne wrote: Hi Sheila Yes it's a shock at how quick it comes out.  I decided to buzz my hair at day 9, I had short hair to start with anyway, but wanted something that was under my control, so took the dog clippers and buzzed it off.  Then just had stubble that rubbed off over the next few days. Having a bald head was liberating in some ways.  It was summer while I was bald so the breeze on my head felt really nice.  Not having to wash my hair and worrying about how it looked like was good too lol no more bed hair! It will grow back.  I had curly hair naturally so was wondering what it would grow out like - I had tiny little ringlets for a while.  Now it's back to its normal self, but is softer and thinner than it was, but the thin hair is probably more from the AI I'm on than anything else. Sending you (((hugs)))) Trish
Posts.Title: I KNEW hair loss was coming, but.. SheilaR SheilaR

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2012 09:18PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Kane I really feel for you - I had taxotere two years ago and it was horrible.  I thought I was going to die - and for a while I hoped I would lol. I was supposed to have 3 treatments, and after the first one the onc decreased the dose by 10% hoping that would help.  It was marginally better, but still pretty bad.  He and I decided not to go ahead with treatment number 3. I know this doesn't help you too much, but wanted to send you  big gentle ((((hugs))))) Trish xoxo
Posts.Title: Landed in hospital after 2nd treatment kane744 KeepingFaith69

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2012 08:15PM Trisha-Anne wrote: I just wanted to chime in and say don't be afraid of pain. I had a mx and had no pain - I was uncomfortable for a week or so - couldn't really lift my arms up above my head, and the drains didn't bother me at all - they were a nuisance more than anything, and I had one in for more than 2 weeks!  Didn't feel it come out at all.  When you have a mx all the nerve endings are cut, so everything around where the breast used to be was numb.  I'm getting more feeling back now, but that has been very slow. I chose not to have reconstruction.  I don't handle anaesthetics very well - I threw up for 30 hours after my mx - that was the worst part about the whole thing. I had a port put in a month later as I had to do 12 months of Herceptin, and that time didn't throw up, but found that the anaesthetist had given me almost every anti nausea medication known to man to stop it - it worked! lol So - please don't panic over the pain part, it's really not worth it.  Chemo is hard but doable - and you may not need to do that. ((((hugs)))) to you both - this is a terrible place to find yourself, but you will get through it Trish
Posts.Title: Sister and I just diagnosed within a week of each other bevg49 AnewBeginning

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2011 11:14PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Hi whitty I'll add my affirmation of what lago has said.  Her2 is not to be messed with, and it seems to work better with chemo.  As my bs said - short term pain for long term gain.  I've finished chemo now and just doing Herceptin and Arimidex (the estrogen sucker :-) ).  While chemo isn't a walk in the park, it really is doable, and I'd much rather increase my chances of surviving, even with the small chance of getting another cancer than the high risk of dying within a couple of years because of my bc. While your surgery will probably have gotten all the cancer in the form of your tumour, there is still a very high chance that there are cancer cells floating around in your bloodstream.  Chemo will (hopefully) kill these off. I've seen the movie "Living Proof" it was very inspiring. Hang in there - just take one day at a time. ((((Hugs)))))) Trish

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2012 01:01PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Hi Scrabblelady I'm similar to you - finished chemo last Feb, but have my last Herceptin on 17th this month (Yay!!). During chemo my nails were really strong and grew despite the chemo.  I too have weak nails that now chip or break off very easily.  I'm on Arimidex and I'm not sure if it's just the Herceptin or the combo of that with the Arimidex that's causing my nail problems.  I see you are ER- so you won't have the Arimidex.  Maybe just the Herceptin.  Give it time, I think that H does cause weaker nails.  I was lucky I didn't have any nail issues with my toenails either. Try putting some nail hardener on - that helps. :-)  Trish
Posts.Title: Finernails Scrabblelady Trisha-Anne

Posts.Content: May 2, 2012 08:29PM Trisha-Anne wrote: In Australia it means the same as in Britain and not usually used in polite conversation.  A "wanker" here is someone who is stupid, idiotic, a jerk.  Usually only applies to men lol and interstingly is used more often than wank. I must admit the title really caught my eye too, and have had a laugh.  Elizabeth - you've certainly taken a lot of minds off bc today!
Posts.Title: Just Need to Wank sbelizabeth autism_mom

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2012 03:13PM Trisha-Anne wrote: I'm in Australia and had chemo over our summer months.  It was interesting, I don't remember being too hot (and we can get hot here girls!).  I did FEC and don't recall sitting in front of a fan, but when I did Taxotere, I got cold.  During my first treatment I actually put flannelette sheets on the bed and had a goose down comforter and was still cold. I guess we are all different. I hope you get through the summer ok - it's starting to get cold here, we are in the middle of autumn and there's snow predicted for the mountains about 150 miles to the south of us :-) Trish
Posts.Title: Summer Heat and Chemotherapy sandrav Shrek4

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2013 05:29PM Trisha-Anne wrote: My bs talked my out of having a bmx and I wish I hadn't let him.  I had both IDC and ILC and it's the ILC that worries me as it has a higher risk of coming back in the other breast. Don't let your bs talk you out of anything you really want to do, if your gut is telling you to do something, then do it.  Of course that's easy for me to say here in Australia as our health system will allow that to happen very easily - but dealing with your medical insurance issues over there will make that decision a bit harder if you are refused cover. Best of luck to you Trish

Posts.Title: New... Jennt28 patty9999

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2012 09:22PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Melmcbee The steroids won't be helping at the moment.  Once you are finished those loosing will be easier.  It's hard to exercise when you are doing chemo, you don't have the energy. I put on a heap of weight during chemo and then more just after I finished.  I've been on an AI for 19 months now, and in the past 5 months or so have lost 25lb - I still have a lot to lose, but I'm getting there. Once you have finished with the stress of chemo, the stress of finishing treatment and the stress of having such an emotional upheaval in your life, you'll be able to focus your mind on loosing weight. Don't beat yourself up about it - it will happen, you have to give yourself time. I'm 2 years out from my mx and 19 months pfc and I'm feeling fantastic!  There is life after chemo and bc, but it takes a little while to get there. Sending you ((((hugs))))) Trish
Posts.Title: Will I ever quit gaining weight??? melmcbee LtotheK

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2014 05:51PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Bippy I did three rounds of FEC without too many problems. Then did my first round of Taxotere and it was brutal. Went in for my second round that the onc reduced by 25%, but still brutal. I really thought it was going to kill me. The onc decided I couldn't do the last round, and I was soooo happy. But I still worry that skipping that last round will come back to bite me. I don't think that will ever go away. If your tx isn't completely brutal and putting you in hospital it's very worthwhile finishing if you possibly can. Then you can live the rest of your life without worrying that that last tx would have been the one that made the cancer completely gone.

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2013 09:49PM Trisha-Anne wrote: myers - are you on hormonal treatment? An AI or Tamoxifen? I had a terrible time with memory loss and confusion while I was on Arimidex. I was on it for 14 months, and went off it and onto Aromasin. The difference was amazing - I got my brain back. AI's can cause "chemo brain" too - even though they aren't chemo. Trish
Posts.Title: Memory Loss and or Confusion myers421 jeni72

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2011 03:53PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Hi Jen Glad everything went well with you.  The next few days will be hard waiting for results. With regard to the cold caps, I think they are reasonably common in the big hospitals in Australia - just not widely advertised. The Canberra Hospital has them, and I decided against them, mainly because I wasn't keen on the -30degree temp that they operate at.  I figured that going through chemo was enough, with out a severely cold head lol. Yes I lost my hair, but I was resigned to that, and it has grown back.   I had short hair to start with though, so now it's actually a little longer than I normally wear it.  It doesn't look quite as long because of the curls lol. I would imagine that a major hospital such as RPA would have cold caps.  As everyone has said before - it's a matter of choice. Jen, take your time to recover from your surgery. You've been through a lot, and just the anaesthetic will take time to leave your body, let alone the trauma you've been through in the past few weeks.  It's unfortunate that your Mum is visiting at such a bad time, especially if she isn't well. Trish xoxo

I also did 12 months of Herceptin and am on Arimidex.  Now my nails have ridges, are weak and flake very easily. I have no long term effects from the chemo though.  I did have some heartburn occasionally for a few months after chemo - had never had it before. Trish

Posts.Title: Just Need to Wank sbelizabeth autism_mom

Posts.Content: May 8, 2011 06:18PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Hi girls For those of you who have always had straight hair and now have to deal with chemo curls, just remember that you never, never brush curls.  They will go haywire! :-)  You need to use a comb with very wide teeth. I've always had curly hair and my hair has always been extremely dry - heaven knows how it will grow in after chemo lol - I can't imagine it being curlier or any drier. You need lots of good styling product - something that you leave in, this will help with the dryness too. I'm now 12 weeks pfc, and my hair is coming back well.  It's still fairly thin - ie I can still see a lot of scalp on the top of my head.  The sides are really thick though.  I've always thought the sides grew quicker than the top - will have to tell my hairdresser that I won that arguement lol.  I wonder too if the Herceptin is slowing the growth down a bit.  But the growth does seem to have suddenly speeded up over the past 2 weeks or so - so maybe not. I had to pluck my eyebrows for the first time yesterday - I'm actually happier about the eyebrows and eyelashes coming back than the hair :-)  Not so happy about the chin hair :-( Trish
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2012 08:59PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Lyn I had one breast removed, and sometimes wish I had both taken.  I found wearing a soft singlet (like a man's singlet, but smaller) helped.  It was soft and didn't hurt under the arm.  I now wear an Ahhh bra lol - it's so comfortable I don't know why I didn't try it sooner. Like all of us who have had a mx - I got a huge shock when I saw my tummy.  It's 15 months since surgery - and I still hate my tummy lol I don't shave under my arms any more.  For a long time, it just felt too weird - because it was numb - it still is but not as bad (does that make sense?), but the hair hasn't really grown back properly there since chemo - and that's one thing I'm not complaining about.  I don't wear anything sleeveless, so not shaving isn't a big deal.  Trish

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2012 07:48AM Trisha-Anne wrote: lol - a singlet - I guess you guys call them something else over there.  Very hard to explain if you don't know what I mean, but it's what we put on very young babies under their clothes.  Men and women here wear them too.  Try googling "Bonds singlets" and look for an Aussie site. They are so comfortable, and are made of 100% cotton. Let me know how you go Trish

I really feel for you, sending you lots of hugs. Trish xoxoxo
Posts.Title: Docetaxel/Taxotere question rabbit Trisha-Anne

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2011 05:46PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Hi Ellen I just stopped after the second round.  For me the Herceptin was going to be the critical thing, and having done 5 out of 6 treatments was acceptable. Have you had your taxol treatment yet?  Keeping my fingers crossed that it is gentler on you. Trish xoxo
Posts.Title: Docetaxel/Taxotere question rabbit Trisha-Anne

Posts.Content: Trisha-Anne wrote: Twelve months ago today I had my first chemo treatment, and I wanted to let all you lovely sisters out there who are starting or in the early days that you will get through it. I should have started two days earlier, but while sitting in the chemo chair and getting prepped I had a seizure.  I spent the day in Emergency instead.  I was so stressed about starting chemo and what they were going to put in my body that my subconscious decided I wasn't going to have chemo that day. It really wasn't worth a seizure over.  You can't feel it going in (that was one of my fears) and I never vomited once on chemo. It's really scary to have to go through chemo, but it does finish and the oncs can manage most of the se's efficiently.  There is a wealth of information on here from others who have done the treatment, and it's all good information. I just want to encourage you all who are starting - don't panic over it, remember to breathe and drink lots of water lol It's a long and hard road, but it doesn't go on forever and will finish.  Just take one day at a time, deal with everything in little steps and it will be a bit more manageable.  And we are all here to hold your hand when you need it. Twelve months later and for me it's a memory - not a nice one - but a memory.  I now have only three more Herceptin treatments to go and then no more visits to the oncology ward YAY!!! Sending love and hugs to you all Trish xoxo I have made a long journey and been to a strange land and I've seen the dark man very close ... The Herceptin is slowing regrowth down a bit, when that's finished I expect it will speed up the growth.  I always had really, really thick hair too - would get it thinned every 5-6 weeks when I had it trimmed.  It's not as thick as it was (but thick enough) - but again I expect that to return to normal after Herceptin. Trish xoxo

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2011 09:02PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Keeping Faith - I'm so sorry you've had this happen (((hugs))))  This disease really is awful.  Good luck with your surgery, and at least you know what to expect from chemo. xoxoxo Racy, it will get there - patience lol, I know it's hard, but your hair seems to be on track, you'll get those hair extensions before too long. Trish xoxox
Posts.Title: For everyone about to start chemo Trisha-Anne Bonseye

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2011 05:10PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Bonseye - how did your first treatment go?  I was thinking of you, and hoping your first treatment was gentle on you. Trish xoxo
Posts.Title: For everyone about to start chemo Trisha-Anne Bonseye

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2012 10:53PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Barbiecorn I've been going to a chiropractor for years, I couldn't survive without one lol.  I had two serious neck injuries many years ago within a month or eachother and suffered for around 10 years with headaches from it.  He has made me function again. After my mx I didn't see him for around 2 months and then saw him again regularly (I have always gone every 4 weeks for an adjustment) and have had no problems with getting used to a one sided chest.  I don't really remember having any pain post mx. You have to find a good one though - there are some quacks out there.  Mine does xrays to see how the spine is first and works from there.  I always have my neck and back adjusted.  After being on Arimidex for 14 months I have a lot of joint pain now, and he helps with that as well. Trish
Posts.Title: Chiropractor barbiecorn barbiecorn

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2011 07:28PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Hi Rabbit I found FEC to be very do-able, but had lots of problems on Taxotere.  Not everyone has problems, and I'll keep my fingers crossed that you fly through it too. Firstly - I didn't have any anti nausea meds on Taxotere.  And I didn't need them.  My main problems were extreme taste change - everything tasted like crap - even the air I was breathing smelled like chemicals.  This made it hard to keep hydrated - the water tasted like mud - that made me feel a bit sick and also I had really bad diahrroea and that made me feel a bit sick too. I felt like I'd been run over by a truck.  It was like having the flu - but 10 times worse.  On top of that (and the bad diahrroea) I had mouth ulcers (despite doing everything I was supposed to, to stop them), bad heartburn and blisters "down there"  I ended up having to use baby wipes to clean myself after going to the loo and then putting Bepanthon (used here in Oz for babies and nappy rash) to try to help.  Extreme fatigue, but up half the night for the first couple of nights because of the steroids - and had a bad steroid "crash" after the first round. My second round was reduced as I was having such a bad reaction, and that helped a bit - but my Onc stopped me at two treatments.  My body couldn't handle the Taxotere.  I'm comfortable with that - my life saving drug is the Herceptin, which I'm on until January . I didn't have Neulasta shots - they aren't done routinely here in Oz, and luckily I didn't have any fingernail issues or neuropathy. I really hope you don't have the problems I had - it isn't common, so you will probably sail through treatments. Hugs to you Trish xoxo
Posts.Title: Docetaxel/Taxotere question rabbit Trisha-Anne

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2011 07:59PM Trisha-Anne wrote: That's one of the great things about being sick in Australia - we don't have to worry about the cost of treatment.  Pretty much everything is covered.  I only ever paid a co-payment of around $35 for each script that was expensive.  If it was a cheaper medication, I didn't pay anything at all. Our Medicare seems to work really well.  All my scans that I have now are completely free, which helps a lot. Are you taking something for the heartburn?  I still have occasional heartburn, and take something for it - but while on chemo took a tablet everyday, which helped a lot. Trish xoxo
Posts.Title: Docetaxel/Taxotere question rabbit Trisha-Anne

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2011 10:32PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Hi Mallory I don't think it's an emergency to have breast cancer.  I had my biopsy on 14 Sept and didn't didn't have my mastecomy until 14 October.  My cancer was quite aggressive, and the breast surgeon advised me that a wait of that long wasn't of any consequence.  It gives you time to sort yourself out and get things straight in your mind.  Of course I wouldn't put it off too long, that wouldn't be good.  But I don't know what the "guidelines" are for this, or even if there are any. I'm sure there will be someone come along who will know if there is. Meanwhile - don't stress yourself - I know easier said than done.  I too lost a lot of weight in between diagnosis and treatment - but unlike you - I slept like a baby - I was exhausted from all the worry. Let us know how you get on. ((((hugs))))) Trish
Posts.Title: how long between diagnosis and surgery? Mallory107 withlove

Posts.Content: May 16, 2011 05:57PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Hi Coffeegirl Is the "D" part of the treatment Docetaxol (Taxotere)?  If it is then you'll find a thread in this part of the form called "Taxotere is a nightmare" it might help you to know what to expect. Don't panic - not everyone has a bad reaction to Taxotere.  Some women find it easier than the FEC part.  I wasn't one, and found FEC relatively easy.  Taxotere really was a nightmare for me, and I couldn't do the last dose because of the extreme reactions I had from it.   I'm sorry you have to go through this - it's not easy, but the biggest thing to remember is to make sure you drink lots and lots and lots of water :-)  Trish xoxo
Posts.Title: FEC-D Experiences Lou10 Trisha-Anne

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2012 10:50PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Hello Pat I'm so sorry you are going through all this, you've had so much to deal with already. I had a single mx 2 years ago - I had pretty large breasts, I'm in Australia so not sure if our sizes are the same as yours but I was a 38DD and when my breast was removed it weighed 1.1kg, which is almost 2 1/2 pounds.   I hated looking at myself with just one breast for a long time, but now it doesn't worry me. I also had ILC and asked my bs to take both breasts. He talked me out of it, and I really, really wish I'd insisted.  I don't want the worry I have now that it will come back in the other breast.  I've already had a scare (just a couple of weeks ago) where I found new lumps in my "good" breast. I wear a prosthesis - although only when I'm out or have visitors - and it's pretty good.  I don't wear anything at home, not even a bra and don't feel lopsided or off balance, although I think it took a couple of months for my body to get used to it.  I don't really remember as I was going through chemo at the time and too busy with se's from that lol. You will have to make your own decision (I know doesn't everyone tell you that! ) but for my part I'm used to being one sided, the foob doesn't bother me, but I do wish I'd had them both off. Good luck with your decision and let us know how you go. Sending you gentle (((((hugs)))))  Trish xoxo
Posts.Title: To be flat or uniboob, please help Frapp Lily55

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2012 04:40PM Trisha-Anne wrote: I have major problems with sleep at the moment, but that's from Arimidex.  While doing chemo - I could sleep anywhere any time!  Sometimes nodded off in public which was embarrasing lol I think when you are on chemo it's the steroids that muck up your sleep cycle more than anything else. I take melatonin - my doctor prescribed it for me as you can't buy it easily in Australia - but you girls in the States can get it fairly easily.  It's not supposed to be habit forming and is a natural substance.  You can always give it a go, but check with your doc first. Trish
Posts.Title: CAN NOT SLEEP...UGH!!!! lanagraves Makratz

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2011 08:37AM Trisha-Anne wrote: Claire ((((hugs))))) I didn't do the chemo you are on, but my particular regime was hard on me.  I kept saying to anyone who would listen - why can't they put us in a coma for the week of treatment!!??  Fatigue is bad, I used to fall asleep almost anywhere - even in public :-) Food tasted awful - and I had a lot of trouble keeping the water intake up during my last two treatments - it just tasted like crap.  That didn't help - being hydrated makes an amazing difference. Fear of recurrance - well we all live with that and each of us has to deal with it in our own way.  I keep saying to myself, if it never comes back, then I'll have gone through all that worry for nothing, if it does come back, I'll just have to deal with it then.  Of course that's easier said than done, and when you are going through chemo it's even harder as all your defences are down. I ended up having to take things an hour at a time during chemo - never mind a day at a time! It feels like it will never end - but it will, and saying that doesn't help how you are feeling now.  Cry when you want to - rant when you want to - it helps to get it out. I'm nine months PFC - my hair is back, my eyelashes and eyebrows are back (well it's all a bit thin at the moment, but will thicken up once Herceptin is finished) and life is looking a lot better.  I still have dark days, but nothing like while on chemo. I can thoroughly sympathise with you.  You need a good cry, a good cuddle and some sleep and lots of water. Trish xoxoxox

I'm planning on having my port out in February sometime - my last Herceptin treatment is mid January (YAY!), if I'm really lucky, maybe I can have them done at the same time and cut down on the number of anaesthetics I have.  Now wouldn't that work out well if it were possible :-) Trish

Posts.Content: Trisha-Anne wrote: Hello all I've been pretty lucky in that I only had my sentinal nodes out.  I've never had LE. But - I have an absolutely HUGE ganglion on my wrist - I had it before bc, was going to have it operated on and then found out about the bc and it never got done.  It should be removed, it's the biggest one the surgeon had ever seen, he was actually quite excited by it!  It's not really one ganglion, but a cluster of about 6 of them, and it's slowly growing. I'm wondering if having it removed might cause LE.  Has anyone had surgery on their arm for something that had nothing to do with bc? I should elaborate and say it is my left arm - same side as the mx. Trish I have made a long journey and been to a strange land and I've seen the dark man very close ... Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2013 01:47PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Dear Milane I found out about my cancer the day before my wedding anniversary too - and that was three years ago last week! You will get through this - it's hard, one minute everything's ok and the next you are numb and scared and it feels like you are suddenly living someone else's life. I'm here three years later to tell you that you will get through it.  This board is the most wonderful resource you'll come accross.  Come here to ask questions, vent, cry, rant and get hugs.  The women here have seen it all and will support you every step of the way. You are in a really hard place at the moment, once you see your health team and have a treatment plan in place things will get a bit easier for you. Sending you lots and lots of ((((hugs)))) and I hope you get to do something special tomorrow.  My DH and I went and had lunch after the first appointment with the breast surgeon. Trish xoxo

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2014 01:26AM Trisha-Anne wrote: Hi Doona So sorry you've had to join us.  You will feel more in control when you know what to expect and what your treatment plan will be.  There's an Australian Sisters thread you might want to join in here: https://community.breastcancer.org/forum/138/topic/762058?page=1 There are a few girls in Brisbane who are regulars on the thread, and the rest of us are from all over Oz. Treatment in Oz is very similar to the US, but there are a few quirky things that are a bit different. Remember to breathe, you will come through this, and we'll help you every step of the way. Trish xoxo
Posts.Title: results are in Doona Hopeful82014

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2012 11:01PM Trisha-Anne wrote: I've been told it will take as long to get over treatment as the time you are on it. So if you've done 3 months of chemo - it will take 6 months to get over it.  Add in the 12 months of Herceptin - you've still got a way to go. I finished chemo in late Feb last year and finished Herceptin in Jan this year, so still have a way to go.  I do feel pretty good most of the time - not like before bc, but much better than while in treatment. I'm also on Arimidex, and that's causing most of my problems at the moment.  I've developed arthritis in hands, wrists, elbows, knees, ankles, feet shoulder and lower back.  I will see the onc next month and look at what my alternatives are. Herceptin will slow down the growth of your hair.  I had a hair cut in October 2010 just before my mx, then didn't get another one until Dec 2011 - and that was more shaping than anything.  Since I finished Herceptin in Jan, I've had 2 full haircuts - but I keep my hair fairly short and have always had to have a trim every 5-6 weeks. Give yourself some time - it may be the Tamox that's giving you grief more than anything else.  I too had some balance issues - and still have to be careful when I'm not wearing flat shoes.  I don't wear stilletos lol haven't done that since my 30's, but I do have some shoes with a 3/4 inch heel and have to be careful.  But that's not so bad these days. Your body has been through so much in the past 18-19 months, it needs to recover.  You don't say how old you are - but if you are on Tamox, you must be relatively young.  I'm 55 this year and will take longer to get over all this than a 30 or 40 year old. (((hugs)))) Trish
Posts.Title: 10 months after chemo and feeling lousy elena1 elena1

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2014 06:06PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Nicole, your mum loved her family so much, it was heartwarming to read her posts on the Aussie thread. She was overjoyed to meet and spend some time with her beautiful grandson. She has raised a lovely caring woman in you and her love story with her darling husband is an inspiration to us all. Of course she waited for you to be there to say goodbye. This disease is, as you so rightly described it, a bitch. I hope that one day we will find a cure for it.  In the meantime, my heart is so sad at this news, even though we've been expecting it. We miss her on the Aussie thread, but we are all so glad she spent some time with us. She's a very, very special lady. My love to you and all the family. This is a crappy time for you all. Karen is at peace now and will be around you whenever you need her love and support, just think of her and how much she loved you. Trish xoxo
Posts.Title: Latest news on Kazzie61 chrissyb Annie62

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2012 12:18PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Hi Pinkgirl FEC can be really hard for some, and it sounds like it is for you.  I'm in Australia and found that I was given lots of anti nausea meds that helped a lot with the nausea - if you've been given them, make sure you take them, whether or not you feel you need them.  It's easier to stop the nausea before it starts than try to deal with it once it's started.  If you haven't been given any - you need to make sure you get some - especially Emend. FEC also seems to mess with your head, it's probably a lot to do with the steroids you will have been given as well.  I found all I could do was cry when I needed to and let it out.  There's not a lot you can do about it, and there doesn't seem to be any way you can stop it, so just go with the flow. Do you like listening to music?  I found that helped quite a lot, it takes me "out of myself" if that makes sense.  I tried to read too - but had bad chemo brain and could hardly remember what I'd read the page before, so had to read light things that didn't take a lot of brain power lol.  Just remember there are lots of us who have been where you are now - you are not alone (((((hugs)))) It will get better, you know that - but it's going to take some time.  While going through chemo - just take one hour at a time.  Sleep as much as you can and drink as much water as you can - that will help flush your system.  I was drinking around 3 litres a day and trust me - it really helps. Hang in there - it seems like this will never end for you at the moment, I know.  Just do what you have to to get through Trish xoxox
Posts.Title: Nearly finished chemi can Anyone tell me wot happens niw Pinkgirl01 Pinkgirl01

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2012 07:07PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Hi Pinkgirl I'm glad you have the antiemetics - they really do help - oh and I found jelly beans helped too.  Something to have on your stomach when you don't feel like eating, and they have glucose in them  and that helps - I hope they are called the same thing there lol. I am two years out now - was dx 2 years ago yesterday  with both ILC and IDC.  Had a mx and did 3 rounds of FEC and was supposed to do 3 rounds of Taxotere.  I tolerated FEC fairly well - wasn't great, but I go through it.  Taxotere though was another story.  I honestly wished I could have died for a while.  I wasn't throwing up - didn't even get any antiemetics for it, not really needed.  But pain everywhere in my body.  If you've ever had the "real" flu - not a bad cold, then it was probably 10 times worse than that.  Add to that terrible heartburn, mouth ulcers and extreme diahroea.  It was terrible.  My onc decreased the dose for the next round and that was a little bit better, but still bad, so he didn't want me to do the last treatment.  I was also HER2+ so had to do 12 months of Herceptin.  That was no-where near as bad as chemo - but towards the end I was getting very tired and the diahroea returned. Finally finished in January this year.  I'm now on Aromasin as I was ER+ as well. I look back on those horrible days of chemo now and I really feel for you - I remember so well the feelings of hopelessness and how I thought it was never going to end.  I would start crying uncontrollably over nothing really (apart from being bald, swelling up and my chest disfigured lol) and not knowing how I would come through the other side. These boards are amazing - I've made some wonderful friends - and we are all there for eachother, we understand like no-one else does. I wish I could be there with you to give you a big hug and just hold your hand while you are feeling so horrible - but just imagine that I am there, everyone on here would be if they could - but everyone's behind you 100%, because we know how you are feeling. I'm feeling pretty good now - in fact wonderful!! I've come out the other side, and life is great.  Breast cancer took over my life for 18 months or so - but now I can move on and know that I've done all that I can to beat it and not have it come back. So long as you recognise that the chemo really is messing with your head and just go with the flow it's a bit easier. As I said before cry when you need to, rant and rave on here when you need to as well - it will help. I hope you have some support at home? Partner? Parents? Someone to lean on? Sending you gentle ((((((hugs)))) Trish xoxxo
Posts.Title: Nearly finished chemi can Anyone tell me wot happens niw Pinkgirl01 Pinkgirl01

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2012 07:09PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Oh!! forgot! The weather here - it's spring and the blossoms are all out and the bees are busy and we've had the coldest winter I can remember for a while, but it's starting to warm up now.  This afternoon we had a huge thunderstorm with bucketloads of rain and some hail - it's that unstable spring weather we get here. I'm on 8.5 acres just south of Canberra - and it's the most beautiful place in the world to live lol Trish xoxxo

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 06:50AM Trisha-Anne wrote: Emily I did three rounds of FEC every three weeks for three cycles and had my first Taxotere yesterday.  FEC was doable - but not fun.  I had constant diarroeha (sp?), heartburn and emotional ups and downs.  Taste changes too - everything tasted like metal or cardboard for around six days or so. Taxotere yesterday and still waiting for the bomb to drop.  It's also giving me bad taste changes, but the steroids I've been taking that they give you for three days is also messing with my sleeping.  So tired and out of sorts today. Don't worry too much about the FEC - take all the anti nausea meds they give you and you won't be sick - you may feel a bit queasy from time to time, but it's not too bad. Let us know how you go - I'll be thinking of you Trish

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2011 04:37PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Bonseye, you are very welcome.  I forgot about the hair loss!!  I lost my hair too - but now it's all grown back in and I don't think about it too much.  I even had a trim about 4 weeks ago lol Being bald didn't worry me too much, I saved so much time not having to worry about my hair each day, and also didn't have to shave my legs for so long :-)  That's a bonus! lol I'll be thinking of you tomorrow for your first treatment, just relax and go with the flow.  I even ate lunch during chemo treatments.  Make sure you take something to keep you amused while you are there - books, ipad or whatever you are into - it will help to pass the time. Trish xoxox

Posts.Title: Bad Experience at the fitter? crystalphm 3jaysmom

Posts.Content: May 26, 2012 07:35PM Trisha-Anne wrote: I'll add my experiences here. I had 3 doses of FEC, which on the whole wasn't too bad. I had taste changes and diahorrea but wasn't sick. Took all the meds I was given and that helped. Felt a bit queasy from time to time but never vomited. Drank lots and lots of water, sorry not sure of what the conversion is, but I drank around 3 liters a day. I worked through it all, but usually fairly short days, mainly because of the fatigue. I chose to buzz my head before it started falling out, and I did it with the dog clippers - they worked a treat. The next round was to have been 3 doses of Taxotere. Taxotere and I didn't agree, and I only did 2 doses. Extreme muscle and bone pain. Extreme taste change to the point I couldn't even drink water without feeling nauseous. Extreme diahorea, mouth sores, blisters "down below" and so fatigued I couldn't drag myself out of bed. Not everyone gets the same se's and some people get very few. Just be prepared and the main thing to do is drink lots and lots of water and listen to your body. Good luck with your treatments, and may they be gentle on you. Trish
Posts.Title: Chemo advice from veterans? Please post!!!! ElleBee pamelahope

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2012 08:26PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Frapp so good to hear from you.  Yes - you definitely made the right decision.  Wow 3cm in the "good" breast, now it's gone.  You are starting to heal, that tight feeling lasts a little while but gradually disappears.  I never needed pain meds, it never got too bad, I'm hoping it's the same for you. Good for you for going out "natural" lol  I'm hoping everything else goes well for you too. Sending you big ((((hugs)))) Trish xoxo
Posts.Title: To be flat or uniboob, please help Frapp Lily55

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 05:00PM Trisha-Anne wrote: I had 3 cycles of FEC and have just had the 2nd of 3 cycles of Taxotere (I think it might be the D part of your treatment? Docetaxol?) I found FEC to be relatively easy.  Not a walk in the park, but not too bad.  The main problem with FEC is that it can cause nausea - and I had so much medication to stop the nausea that I never really had a problem.  The main thing to remember with FEC is take all the anti nausea medication - even if you think you don't need it.  It's easier to control the nausea than try to stop it once it has started.  I also had bad diarrhoea, heartburn and headaches.  These can also be controlled with medication.  I had taste changes, nothing tasted very good, and I generally wasn't terribly hungry.  My bad days were the day of infusion - I'd get a migraine that night, and days 4 and 5. The Taxotere though is another kettle of fish.  It has been quite awful.  No nausea, but extreme taste changes, just drinking water is a battle as it tastes like mud.  Very bad flu like symptoms - these last around 5 days for me.  Diarrhoea again - very bad, heartburn, mouth ulcers, sore nose and headaches.  There's a thread for on this board called "Taxotere is a nightmare".  There's also steroids that you have to take with the Taxotere - and they can cause some issues as well. With both treatments there is also the constant tiredness.  The first treatment of FEC and the first and second treatment of Taxotere had to be monitored fairly closely in case of allergic reactions. I wouldn't reccomend doing any of the treatments without someone with you - I defenitely needed someone to drive me in and home. Of course everyone is different - you may or may not have any of the se's, you may be one of the lucky ones and sail through with minimal se's. Good luck - chemo's no fun, but there are lots of wonderful supportive ladies here who can help you through this emotionally. Trish
Posts.Title: FEC-D Experiences Lou10 Trisha-Anne

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2011 04:56PM Trisha-Anne wrote: What's the pec muscle distortion?  Is that the swelling I seem to have near my collar bone now? Trish
Posts.Title: I miss my breasts! topless karen1956

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2012 08:43PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Hi Amy I had FEC rather than AC, then taxotere.  For me the FEC was not nice, but doable.  Taxotere can be pretty savage though.  It's a completely different drug and se's don't normally include nausea, which you can get pretty good meds for.  Taxotere for me was like getting the flu - not a cold, but full blown flu - but 10 times worse. I have to stress though, that not everyone gets the same se's and you might just sail through it. There's a couple of threads about Taxotere on here - they are worth reading. Good luck with your treatment, I hope it is gentle on you.  Remember to drink lots of water and take it one day (and sometimes one hour) at a time. Trish xoxo
Posts.Title: A/C or taxotere, which is worse? amylovesbubby Trisha-Anne

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2014 10:45PM Trisha-Anne wrote: Kelly, there will be others who come on here to support you, this is a wonderful community. I know it's easier said than done, but you are in one of the worst stages right now - waiting to see what you are dealing with and how it will be dealt with. I just want you to know that you'll be supported by all the amazing ladies (and men) on this site, and while your journey (I hate that description of it, but it really is a journey) may not be easy, you'll have lots of support. I am almost four years out from a diagnosis of aggressive cancer, and I'm doing really well - so don't think you have an automatic death sentence! Please keep us posted on how you go tomorrow. Sending you warm ((((hugs)))) from Australia! Trish
Posts.Title: It was confirmed today (33 years old). Kelly1217 whatnow

Posts.Content: May 14, 2014 08:55PM Trisha-Anne wrote: You poor thing - you've been through hell and back. I tolerated FEC fairly well, but Taxotere was a nightmare for me.  One thing you could think of is to have weekly Taxol instead of three weekly Taxotere. I think the Taxol is not quite so rough, and it's further reduced as it's done weekly. It may not help, but then again, you may get through it a lot better. As you are HER2- though - it might not be worth the battle you are having now. You probably need to really think about whether you've had enough (and no-one would blame you if you decided you have) and stop the chemo, but feel that you wouldn't regret the decision if the cancer came back or spread.  You are very young - and usually that means you need to try all you can while you are able. But - you could still go through and complete chemo and have it spread or come back. You could also stop now and never have another problem with cancer again. No-one knows. You have to make a decision that you are comfortable with. It's a hard one to make, but no-one can make it for you. Sending you ((((hugs)))) - whatever you decide will be right for you. Trish xoxoxo
Posts.Title: To continue FEC-D treatment... or not? Advice welcome! Tam178 Trisha-Anne

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2014 07:15PM Trisha-Anne wrote: My lump was in exactly the same spot - and I found it just by washing under my arms in the shower.  Thought to myself, this wasn't there yesterday, I'd have felt it!  It was painful to touch, but I think that's because I was poking and prodding at it so much lol. Hope you've found out what it might be by now. Trish
Posts.Title: Can cancer lumps suddenly appear overnight? cgood75 ddbaker

Posts.Content: May 6, 2012 09:07PM Trisha-Anne wrote: When I was dx I was in shock - as we all were :-) My husband encouraged me to have the other breast removed - just in case.  My bs talked us out of that.  Sometimes I wish I had.  Anyway - my husband said to me, I don't care if you have one breast, two breasts or none - it's you that I love. He really doesn't care about the flat side of me.  I still mourn the loss a little bit, but it gets better as time goes on. Trish
Posts.Title: What does your husband/loved one think about your flatness? otter otter
